citeinfo.origin: Northwest and Alaska Fisheries Center, National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), 2725 Montlake Boulevard, Seattle, WA 98112.
citeinfo.title: Evaluation of Standing Stocks of Marine Resources in the Eastern Bering Sea

abstract.p: Standing stock size of any marine ecological group is dependent, besides recruitment, on ecosystem internal consumption and growth and on mortality rates., Growth-rate data are gnarly available, as are fishing and natural mortality rate estimates. The ecosystem internal consumption can be determined by food requirements and composition of food of all components of the marine ecosystem. A static-trophic numerical Bulk Biomass Model that computes the ecosystem internal consumption is programmed and uses an iterative technique to derive plausible standing stocks of various ecological groups, using growth and mortality data. Model computations indicate that the availability of food is the main factor limiting the size of standing stocks of most ecological groups above herbivores; the need for further research on food coefficients, composition of food, and feeding habits is emphasized.

[Reference: Laevastu, T. and F. Favorite. 1976. Evaluation of Standing Stocks of Marine Resources in the Eastern Bering Sea. Northwest and Alaska Fisheries Center Prcoessed Report No. 61. Northwest and Alaska Fisheries Center, National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS), National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA), 2725 Montlake Boulevard, Seattle, WA 98112. pp. 43.]

descript.purpose: To evaluate standing stocks of marine resources in the eastern Bering Sea.
